substitution.copyText: My Lord, his Majesty commended him to you by young| Ostrick who brings back to him that you attend him in the hall, he| tends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that| you will take longer time?| I am constant to my purposes, they follow the kings| pleasure; if his sinces speaks, thine is ready, now or whensoever, pro| vided I be so able as now.| The King and the Queen and all are coming down.| In happy time.| The Queen desires you to are some gent;e entertainment to| Laertes before you go to play.| She well instructs you me.|

''there is a special provi-| dence in the fall of a Sparrow: if it be, 'tis not to come; if it be| ot to come, it will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come,| the readiness is all, since no man of ought he leaves knows what| 'tis to leave betimes, let be.
A table prepared, Drums, Trumpets, and officers with cushions,
King, Queen, and tate, Foils, daggers, and Laertes.
substitution.amendedText: King, Queen, and Ostrick, Foils, and Laertes.

substitution.copyText: Was't Hamlet wrong'd Laertes? never Hamlet,| If Hamlet from himself be ta'en away,| And when he's not himself does wrong Laertes,| Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it:| Who does it then? his madness: it't be so,| Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged,| His madness is poor Hamlet's enemy;
